_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Chevron Phillips Chemical Co., LP - Borger Facility is a manufacturing facility of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP, headquartered in The Woodlands, Texas. The Borger Plant is located in Borger, TX, and is situated on approximately 60 acres. The plant was initially built by Phillips Petroleum and began operating in 1944 as the Philtex Experiment Station. The Philtex Experiment Station became the Philtex Plant and underwent a major expansion in 1959. 



The plant produces a variety of specialty chemicals such as organo-sulfur compounds, high purity hydrocarbons, solvents, diversified organic chemicals, and aromatic polymers. These products are primarily intermediates which customers use to produce finished consumer products such as plastics, solvents and odorants. Since the original RMP filing, the use of allyl alcohol and piperidine have been discontinued and removed from this report. Chemicals used at the facility that exceed the RMP threshold quantity include flammable mixtures which may contain butane, 1,3-butadiene, ethyl chloride, propylene,1-butene, 2-butene, ethyl mercaptan, 2-methylpropene, isobutene, isopentane; and toxics such as hydrogen sulfide, sulfur dioxide, and methyl mercaptan. Since the last filing, reference to the Ryton facility has been removed because it was sold to another company on 12/31/2014.  Ryton was not required to be covered under RMP process. 





ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



Process Safety Management at the Borger Plant complies with the requirements of both the OSHA PSM standard and EPA RMP regulation. The Borger Plant manages all aspects of process safety through employee participation at all levels in the organization. Procedures for employee involvement are detailed in site procedure POL-6020 - Implementation Roles and Responsibilities for EPA RMP and OSHA PSM.  Each element of the PSM and RMP standards is assigned to a responsible organizational position to maintain the systems that ensure compliance with regulatory

requirements and management of that aspect of process safety. Some of the details of this management system include:



     1)    Employee Participation is outlined in the MANAGEMENT LEADERSHIP COMMUNICATION, ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES PROCEDURE (POL-6000) and includes the plant OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) STAR teams. These teams drive safety by focusing individual work groups on safety activities and issues in their area.



     2)    Process Safety Information (PSI) management is managed according to the standards outlined in EHS-6155 - Process Safety Information. This procedure assigns responsible positions for documentation required for demonstration of compliance with OSHA and EPA standards.



     3)    Site procedure POL-6010 - Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provides site-specific details on the conduct and disposition of all unit PHAs. The policy references corporate PHA procedures. The relevant procedures provide oversight and management of the performance of PHAs. Instructions include relevant timelines for report development and review, procedures for recommendation development and tracking, and final report issuance. The corporate procedures for conduct of PHAs and the qualitative assessment of risk include consideration of off-site consequences and harm to the environment or the public. PHAs meet both OSHA and EPA standards for risk identification and analysis.



     4)    Operating procedures are developed, reviewed and kept current by personnel experienced in the operation of that portion of the unit or in the specific job or task. Operational procedure development, Health, Safety and Environmental procedure development, Maintenance procedure development, and the Policy and Procedure Management Process are managed according to the Rules and Procedures Subcommittee Charter. 



     5)    Training for Process Operators is managed by the plant Training Department. Training includes rigorous initial-hire and job-transfer training. Training includes cla

ssroom and on-the-job elements as well as ongoing refresher training for experienced personnel. Refresher training is conducted on a frequency determined by individual need or a maximum three-year cycle.



     6)    The site Mechanical Integrity Program encompasses several functional groups of the Maintenance Department. Compliance includes written procedures for all maintenance activities, inspection and testing schedules, procedures and reports as required by both OSHA and EPA standards.



     7)    Changes to equipment or operations in a covered process follow site procedure POL-6005-Management of Change & Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR). A company-wide software system aids in managing such changes and provides a means of controlling the change process. Steps in the process include required safety and health evaluations, appropriate approval, and pre-startup safety review steps. Action items identified in the process are tracked to completion in the database.



     8)    Site procedure POL-6005-Management of Change & Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) details the conduct of a pre-startup safety review for changes requiring this type of follow-up. The process is designed to ensure system integrity before introduction of hazardous chemicals. Action items identified in the process are tracked to completion in the database.



     9)    Audits for compliance with both the OSHA and EPA regulatory requirements are conducted at least every three years, according to the corporate auditing protocol. Some audits or evaluations of individual process safety elements may be conducted in the intervening years according to a specific need for that area.



     10)Incidents that occur in a covered process are investigated through application of site procedure POL-2010 - Incident Investigation. This procedure provides guidance on use of the appropriate investigation method as well as development of investigation reports and corrective actions or recommendations to prevent recurrence.

A company-wide software system aids in tracking both the investigations and the resulting recommendations and their resolution.



    11)    The site safe work practices are managed through several procedures including POL-3660 -Unit Entry/Exit Policy, POL-3410 - Daily Safe Work Checklist, POL-3480 - High Energy Hot Work Permit Procedure, POL-5055 First Break Procedure for Opening Process Piping and Equipment,  POL-3400 - Energy Isolation Procedure, POL-3430 - Confined Space Entry.



    12)    Management of contract employees follows site procedure POL-2040 - Contractor, Visitor, and Vendor Safety Management Program. The policy includes selection of contractors based on their safety performance, training of contract workers on hazards where they will be working in the plant, and periodic evaluation of the performance of both individual contract employees and the contract company in general at the Borger Plant.



    13)    The Borger Plant has developed an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) to guide responses to various types of emergencies and events. This ICP includes procedures on responding to hazardous material releases, both large and small, and coordination with on- and off-site responders.



The Borger Plant became an OSHA STAR worksite in the Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) in 1999.  The site has maintained a positive STAR status with OSHA annually and on the required recertification schedule since. This voluntary program is a partnership between OSHA and industry to recognize and encourage excellence and improvement in safety programs. STAR certification represents the highest form of recognition OSHA can give a company for outstanding safety performance.





CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTIONS:



Chemical specific preventions identified in Off-site Consequence Analyses (OCAs) for chemical mixtures containing chemicals listed in the RMP Standard might include: pressure relief valves, hydrocarbon area detectors, SO2 detectors, H2S detectors, remote valves for iso

lation of the process, and administrative controls on tank level limit to control inventories of hazardous chemicals.



PHA analyses examine off-site consequences and identify safeguards that can be defined with a discrete probability-of-failure-on-demand. The analysis of risk is based on a qualification of the potential safety and environmental consequences of a given scenario. Corporate policies define the criteria by which these prevention mechanisms must be qualified (EHS-6200-HAZOP-LOPA Procedure and 6205-PHA Procedure). List of Independent Protection Layers (IPLs) meeting these criteria for reliability and effectiveness are maintained within the PHA documentation. IPLs are assigned to preventative maintenance schedules according to the definitions required by the specific equipment/instrumentation classes. 





EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Alarm Systems



Borger has an internal, plant-wide alarm system for fires and emergencies. 



Emergency Responders



To protect onsite workers and property, the Chevron Phillips/Phillips 66 Complex in Borger has fully trained volunteer responders. The Borger Site Complex, including the neighboring refinery, has emergency response capability covering all four rotating shifts to ensure 24-hour coverage. Each shift has a Fire & Safety Specialist (Incident Commander), Fire Brigade members, and Emergency Medical Service/Rescue members. Emergency Response Team (ERT) members receive training in all recognized categories of response (Fire, Haz-Mat, Emergency Medical Treatment, Rescue and Environmental Protection). 



Communications Link to Offsite Responders



The Borger Plant Emergency Operations Center (EOC) is the central communication point for internal and external responders. The EOC is staffed by Management, Environmental, and Health & Safety personnel, as well as individuals who are on call, per the facility Incident Command System. In the City of Borger, emergency assistance is obtained by calling 911 and industry a

ssistance is available through the mutual aid contracts listed below. The Emergency Response and Security Coordinator participates with the Hutchinson County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). In 1998, the Borger Plant initially shared release scenario information with the LEPC.



Mobile Fire Protection Equipment



Emergency response systems include the following list of mobile response equipment:



 M-1 through M-13: Trailer Mounted Fire Monitors

 PT-1: Trailer Mounted Fire Pump

 F-1, F-3, F-4 & F-5: Foam Trailers

 F-2: Portable fire water pump - 4,000 GPM

 P-1: Portable fire water pump - 1,500 GPM

 HT-1: 5" Hose Roll-off

 AT-1: SCBA Trailer

 D-1: D.A.R.T. Transfer Trailer

 D-4: Honda 4x4 ATV

 Unit #1: 2000 GPM International Quality Pumper

 Unit #3: 3000 GPM Smeal Ladder Pumper

 Unit #4: 350 GPM International Pumper

 Unit #5: Initial Response Unit

 Unit #6: Rescue Unit

 Unit #9: Mobile Command Post - 2006 LeBoit Command Vehicle

 Unit #11: CPChem Initial Response Unit

 Unit #12: Basic Life Support Ambulance

 Unit #14: HAZMAT Response Vehicle - Chevrolet 1-ton dually



Members of Mutual Aid Contracts with Other Plants



The Borger plant is a member of the Hutchinson County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) which offers additional emergency response assistance if on-site responders and equipment cannot handle an emergency. The EOC has the authority to request assistance from outside mutual aid contracts.  Also, the Borger Plant offers assistance through the mutual aid contracts to offsite emergencies.





FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Borger facility had one accidental release in the last five years. This release occurred on 15 March 2011, discharging 535 gallons of MeSH/DMS mixture into the atmosphere. There were no injuries or damage either onsite or offsite.





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



As part of the Borger Plant commitment to continuously improving the safety of our processes, some of the initiatives and mea

sures that have been completed or are on-going include:



     1)    Completed a risk-based Building Siting study based on OSHA and API RP guidelines to determine the risk to building occupants from external explosion, fire, or toxic release and developed a plan.



     2)    Adding Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) meeting ANSI/ISA-84.01-1996 and IEC 61511 standards to the processes as determined by hazard and operability (HAZOP) and Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) reviews.



     3)    To monitor the overall effectiveness of the facility's PSM programs, Process Safety Metrics are generated monthly. Metrics are periodically reviewed with all units, departments, and Borger Leadership Team.



     4)    Plant equipment is being assessed for possible Corrosion Under Insulation (CUI) and corrective and preventative measures are being taken to address this potential hazard when necessary.



     5)    A significant, multi-year, multi-functional effort to improve the Mechanical Integrity (MI) documentation and procedures has been initiated.



     6)    Systems are being implemented to identify and confirm "master" values for PSI required by 29 CFR 1910:119 PSM standards. The master values will be used to check and update data stored in the various database storage systems.



     7)    A current project will move the storage of propylene storage from the CPU unit to Unit 5 in order to store the propylene in a more remote location. The Propylene in Unit 5 will then be at quantities above the threshold limit, and therefore, Unit 5 will be added back to this report at the completion of the project. The associated information for CPU and Unit 5 will be updated accordingly at that time.
